{{Short description|American laws on Native American status}} {{for|the film|Blood Quantum (film)}} {{Discrimination sidebar|state=collapsed}} [[Image:Creeks in Oklahoma.png|upright=1.2|thumb|Members of the [[Muscogee (Creek) Nation]] in [[Oklahoma]] around 1877, including some with partial European and African ancestry<ref>Charles Hudson, ''The Southeastern Indians'', 1976, pg. 479</ref>]] {{Native American topics sidebar}}
'''Blood quantum laws''' or '''Indian blood laws''' are laws in the United States that define [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] status by fractions of [[Native American ancestry]]. These laws were enacted by the [[Federal government of the United States|federal government]] and [[State governments of the United States|state governments]] as a way to [[Judicial aspects of race in the United States|establish legally defined racial population groups]]. By contrast, many [[Tribe (Native American)|tribes]] do not include blood quantum as part of their own enrollment criteria. Blood quantum laws were first imposed by white settlers in the 18th century. Blood quantum (BQ) continues to be a controversial topic.
== History of blood quantum law == In 1705, the Colony of [[Virginia]] adopted the "Indian Blood law" that limited the civil rights of Native Americans and persons of one-half or more Native American ancestry.<ref name="ucd2">{{cite web |author=Professor Jack D. Forbes |year=2008 |title=THE BLOOD GROWS THINNER :BLOOD QUANTUM, PART 2 |url=http://nas.ucdavis.edu/Forbes/Blood_Quantum_II.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100610050121/http://nas.ucdavis.edu/Forbes/Blood_Quantum_II.html |archive-date=2010-06-10 |access-date=2009-08-07 |publisher=[[University of California|University of California-Davis]]}}</ref> This also had the effect of regulating who would be classified as Native American. In the 19th and 20th centuries, the US government believed tribal members had to be defined for the purposes of federal benefits or annuities paid under treaties resulting from land cessions.<ref name="naaa2">{{cite book |author=Russell Thornton |url=https://archive.org/details/changingnumbersc0000unse |title=Tribal Membership Requirements and the Demography of "Old" and "New" Native Americans |publisher=[[The National Academic Press]] |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-309-05548-2 |doi=10.17226/5355 |pmid=25121291 |access-date=2009-09-02 |url-access=registration}}</ref> According to [[the Pocahontas Clause]] of the [[Racial Integrity Act of 1924]], a white person in Virginia could have a maximum blood quantum of one-sixteenth Native American ancestry without losing his or her legal status as white.
The [[Indian Removal Act]] and the [[Trail of Tears]] led to a major enumeration of Native Americans as well as controversies and misunderstandings about blood quantum that persist to this day. As they were being forcibly driven out of their ancestral homelands and subjected to [[genocide]],<ref name="Sand2">{{Cite book |author=Christopher D. Haveman |title=Rivers of Sand: Creek Indian Emigration, Forced Relocation, and Ethnic Cleansing in the American South |publisher=University of Nebraska Press |year=2016}}</ref> many Natives understandably feared and distrusted the government and attempted to avoid enumeration. But the only way to do this was to completely flee the Native American community during a time of widespread persecution. Native Americans who tried to refuse, if they were not already in a prison camp, had warrants issued for their arrests;<ref name="Encyclopedia2">{{Cite book |author1=Daniel F. Littlefield |title=Encyclopedia of American Indian Removal, Volume 1 |author2=James W. Parins |publisher=ABC-CLIO |year=2011}} Note: The fact many tried to understandably avoid this, plus the fact that there were multiple waves of departure on the [[Trail of Tears]], each less and less "voluntary", has led to the myth that "enrollment" was somehow optional. If they refused, warrants were issued and people were hunted down by soldiers. They had to sign up or face criminal charges.</ref> they were forcibly rounded up and documented against their will.<ref name="Sand2" /><ref name="Encyclopedia2" /> It is a modern misconception that this enumeration was equivalent to contemporary tribal enrollment, or in any way optional.<ref name="Sand2" />
The concept of blood quantum was not widely applied by the United States government until the [[Indian Reorganization Act|Indian Reorganization Act of 1934]]. At the time, the federal government required persons to have a certain BQ to be recognized as Native American, and thus eligible for financial and other benefits under treaties or sales of land.<ref name="nar2">{{cite journal |author=Spruhan |first=Paul |year=2001 |title=A Legal History of Blood Quantum in Federal Indian Law to 1935 |journal=South Dakota Law Review |publisher=Social Science Electronic Publishing, Inc |volume=51 |issue=1 |ssrn=955032}}</ref> The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 marked the beginning of the US government's widespread application of the blood quantum idea. At the time, for someone to be recognized as Native American and be qualified for financial and other benefits under treaties or land sales, they had to meet a specific BQ requirement set by the federal government. <ref>{{Cite book |last=Ellinghaus |first=Katherine |url= |title=Blood Will Tell: Native Americans and Assimilation Policy |date=2017 |publisher=[[Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press]] |isbn=978-1-4962-0160-7}}</ref>
Native American tribes did not formally use blood quantum law until the [[United States government|government]] introduced the [[Indian Reorganization Act of 1934]], instead determining tribal status on the basis of kinship, lineage, and family ties.<ref name="Tallbear12">{{cite journal |author=Kimberly Tallbear |date=2003 |title=DNA, Blood, and Racializing the Tribe |journal=Wíčazo Ša Review |publisher=University of Minnesota Press |volume=18 |issue=1 |pages=81–107 |doi=10.1353/wic.2003.0008 |jstor=1409433 |s2cid=201778441}}</ref> Some tribes, such as the [[Navajo Nation]], did not adopt the type of written constitution suggested in that law until the 1950s.<ref name="unm2">{{cite web |author=Paul Spruhan |year=2008 |title=THE ORIGINS, CURRENT STATUS, AND FUTURE PROSPECTS OF BLOOD QUANTUM AS THE DEFINITION OF MEMBERSHIP IN THE NAVAJO NATION |url=http://tlj.unm.edu/volumes/vol8/8TLJ1LSPRUHAN.pdf |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112191550/http://tlj.unm.edu/volumes/vol8/8TLJ1LSPRUHAN.pdf |archive-date=2013-11-12 |access-date=2009-08-15 |publisher=Tribal Law Journal}}</ref> Given intermarriage among tribes, particularly those that are closely related and have settled near each other, critics object to the federal requirement that individuals identify as belonging to only one tribe when defining blood quantum. They believe this reduces an individual's valid membership in more than one tribe, as well as costing some persons their qualification as Native American because of having ancestry from more than one tribe but not 1/4 or more from one tribe. Overall, the number of registered members of many Native American tribes has been reduced because of tribal laws that define and limit the definition of acceptable blood quantum.
Native American nations have continued to assert sovereignty and treaty rights, including their own criteria for tribal membership, which vary among them. In the early 21st century, some nations, such as the [[Wampanoag]]{{Vague|reason=Which group of Wampanoag? When?|date=December 2022}} tightened their enrollment criteria and excluded persons who had previously been considered members. Challenges to such policies have been pursued by those excluded.{{Citation needed|date=December 2022}} Native American tribes have maintained their claims to sovereignty and treaty rights, as well as their own membership requirements. By the early 21st century, many Native American tribes had modified their enrollment requirements and banned people who were already considered members. Those who are not members had tried to challenge policies to become a member.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Hill |first=Norbert |url= |title=The Great Vanishing Act: Blood Quantum and the Future of Native Nations |date=2017 |publisher=[[Fulcrum Publishing]] |isbn=9781682750650}}</ref>
== Measuring an individual's blood quantum == A person's blood quantum (BQ) is defined as the fraction of their ancestors, out of their total ancestors, who are documented as full-blood Native Americans. For instance, a person who has one parent who is a full-blood Native American and one who has no Native ancestry has a BQ of 1/2. Nations that use blood quantum often do so in combination with other criteria. There are different BQ that are required for enrollment in different tribes. For example, to be eligible for enrollment, the Omaha Tribe of Nebraska requires a BQ of 1/4 Native American and descent from a registered ancestor, while the Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma just requires lineal descent from a proven Cherokee ancestor recorded on the Dawes Rolls and has no BQ requirements at all. Others use a tiered system, with the [[Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma]] using lineal descent for general enrollment, but requiring a BQ of "at least one-fourth" for all tribal council candidates.<ref name="chlawbl3">{{cite web |title=Tribal Constitution - Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma; Tribal Law Gateway, National Indian Law Library; Native American Rights Fund |url=https://narf.org/nill/constitutions/choctaw/index.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190529184133/https://narf.org/nill/constitutions/choctaw/index.html |archive-date=2019-05-29 |access-date=2019-05-29 |website=narf.org |publisher=National Indian Law Library}}</ref>
== Tribe requirements for membership == Prior to colonization, individual tribes had established their own requirements for membership, including the practice of banishment for those who had committed unforgivable crimes. Some traditional communities still hold to these precontact standards. Tribes that follow lineal descent may require a Native American ancestor who is listed on a prior [http://primeau.org/StandingRock1885families.html tribal rations-issue roll], such as the [[Dawes Rolls]] for the [[Five Civilized Tribes]] in Oklahoma or a late 19th-century [[census]]. In some cases, they may also require a certain percentage of Native American ancestry and demonstrated residence with a tribe or commitment to the community. Few tribes allow members to claim ancestry in more than one tribe. The [[Little Traverse Bay Bands of Odawa Indians]] accept persons of 1/4 Native American ancestry plus documented descent from an ancestor listed in specific records.<ref name="ltbbn2">{{cite web |date=1 January 2014 |title=LTBB |url=http://www.ltbbodawa-nsn.gov/Enroll/Enrollment.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190529181512/http://www.ltbbodawa-nsn.gov/Enroll/Enrollment.html |archive-date=29 May 2019 |access-date=29 May 2019 |website=www.ltbbodawa-nsn.gov |publisher=Little Traverse Bay Bands of Odawa Indians Nation}}</ref> In part, this recognizes that the Odawa people historically had a territory on both sides of what is now the border between the US and Canada. Each federally recognized tribe has established its own criteria for membership.<ref name="naaa3">{{cite book |author=Russell Thornton |url=https://archive.org/details/changingnumbersc0000unse |title=Tribal Membership Requirements and the Demography of "Old" and "New" Native Americans |publisher=[[The National Academic Press]] |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-309-05548-2 |doi=10.17226/5355 |pmid=25121291 |access-date=2009-09-02 |url-access=registration}}</ref> Given the new revenues that many tribes are realizing from gambling casinos and other economic development, or from settlement of 19th-century [[land claims]], some have established more restrictive rules to limit membership.{{citation needed|date=May 2019}} Between 1904 and 1919, tribal members of [[Black Indians in the United States|mixed African and Native American ancestry]] were disenrolled from the [[Chitimacha]] tribe of Louisiana, and their descendants have since then been denied tribal membership.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Lalosttribe Resources and Information |url=http://ww16.lalosttribe.com/louisianas-lost-tribe-our-story.html?sub1=20210513-2322-0504-ae27-b16e968384dd |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221022212922/http://ww16.lalosttribe.com/louisianas-lost-tribe-our-story.html?sub1=20210513-2322-0504-ae27-b16e968384dd |archive-date=2022-10-22 |access-date=2022-10-22 |website=ww16.lalosttribe.com}}</ref>
In 2007 the [[Cherokee Nation]] voted in the majority to exclude as members those [[Cherokee Freedmen]] who had no documented ancestors on the Cherokee-by-blood list of the [[Dawes Rolls]]. However, the Cherokee Supreme Court ruled in 2005 that they were legitimate members of the tribe at that time. After the Civil War, the US required the Cherokee and other Native American tribes that had supported the Confederacy to make new treaties. They also required them to emancipate their slaves and to give full tribal membership to those freedmen who wanted to stay in tribal territory. The Cherokee Freedmen often had intermarried and some had Cherokee ancestry at the time of the Dawes Rolls, qualifying as Cherokee by blood, but registrars typically classified them as Freedmen.
Similarly, in 2000, the [[Seminole Nation of Oklahoma]] attempted to exclude two bands of Seminole Freedmen from membership to avoid including them in the settlement of land claims in Florida, where Seminole Freedmen had also owned land taken by the US government.<ref>Evans, Ben. [http://www.indiancountrytoday.com/home/content/44590087.html "Dems ask DoJ to probe treatment of Indian freedmen."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090522221521/http://www.indiancountrytoday.com/home/content/44590087.html|date=2009-05-22}} ''Indian Country Today,'' 2009-05-08 (retrieved 2010-04-20)</ref><ref name="cr2">{{cite web |author1=Jeff Fogel |author2=Barbara Olshansky |author3=Shayana Kadidal |name-list-style=amp |year=2008 |title=CCR Files Amicus Brief on Behalf of Black Seminoles |url=http://ccrjustice.org/newsroom/press-releases/ccr-files-amicus-brief-behalf-black-seminoles |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111126222309/http://ccrjustice.org/newsroom/press-releases/ccr-files-amicus-brief-behalf-black-seminoles |archive-date=2011-11-26 |access-date=2009-08-15 |publisher=Center for Constitutional Rights}}</ref>
Since 1942, the [[Seminole]] have, at times, tried to exclude [[Black Seminoles]] from the tribe. The freedmen were listed separately on the [[Dawes Rolls]] and suffered [[Racial segregation in the United States|segregation]] in [[Oklahoma]]. More recently, the Seminole refused to share with them the revenues of 20th-century US government settlements of land claims. The [[Center for Constitutional Rights]] has filed an ''amicus'' brief, taking up the legal case of the Black Seminoles and criticizing some officials of the [[Bureau of Indian Affairs]] for collaborating in this discrimination by supporting tribal autonomy in lawsuits. By treaty, after the [[American Civil War]], the Seminole were required to emancipate slaves and provide Black Seminoles with all the rights of full-blood Indian members.<ref name="cr3">{{cite web |author1=Jeff Fogel |author2=Barbara Olshansky |author3=Shayana Kadidal |name-list-style=amp |year=2008 |title=CCR Files Amicus Brief on Behalf of Black Seminoles |url=http://ccrjustice.org/newsroom/press-releases/ccr-files-amicus-brief-behalf-black-seminoles |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111126222309/http://ccrjustice.org/newsroom/press-releases/ccr-files-amicus-brief-behalf-black-seminoles |archive-date=2011-11-26 |access-date=2009-08-15 |publisher=Center for Constitutional Rights}}</ref>
"American Indian tribes located on reservations tend to have higher BQ requirements for membership than those located off reservation....[reference to table] [O]ver 85 percent of tribes requiring more than a one-quarter BQ for membership are reservation based, as compared with less than 64 percent of those having no minimum requirement. Tribes on reservations have seemingly been able to maintain exclusive membership by setting higher blood quanta, since the reservation location has generally served to isolate the tribe from non-Indians and intermarriage with them."<ref>{{Cite book |last=Thornton |first=Russell |title=Changing Numbers, Changing Needs: American Indian Demography and Public Health |date=1996 |publisher=National Academy Press |editor-last=Sandefur |editor-first=Gary D. |pages=108 |chapter=5 Tribal Membership Requirements and the Demography of "Old" and "New" Native Americans}}</ref>
== Issues related to blood quantum laws == Many Native Americans have become used to the idea of "blood quantum".<ref name="ucd22">{{cite web |author=Professor Jack D. Forbes |year=2008 |title=THE BLOOD GROWS THINNER :BLOOD QUANTUM, PART 2 |url=http://nas.ucdavis.edu/Forbes/Blood_Quantum_II.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100610050121/http://nas.ucdavis.edu/Forbes/Blood_Quantum_II.html |archive-date=2010-06-10 |access-date=2009-08-07 |publisher=[[University of California|University of California-Davis]]}}</ref> The blood quantum laws have caused problems in Native American families whose members were inaccurately recorded as having differing full or partial descent from particular tribes.<ref name="ucd22" /><ref name="unm22">{{cite web |author=Paul Spruhan |year=2008 |title=THE ORIGINS, CURRENT STATUS, AND FUTURE PROSPECTS OF BLOOD QUANTUM AS THE DEFINITION OF MEMBERSHIP IN THE NAVAJO NATION |url=http://tlj.unm.edu/volumes/vol8/8TLJ1LSPRUHAN.pdf |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112191550/http://tlj.unm.edu/volumes/vol8/8TLJ1LSPRUHAN.pdf |archive-date=2013-11-12 |access-date=2009-08-15 |publisher=Tribal Law Journal}}</ref><ref name="che2">{{cite web |author=Christina Berry |year=2008 |title=Blood Quantum - Why It Matters, and Why It Shouldn't |url=http://www.allthingscherokee.com/articles_gene_040101.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090610110458/http://www.allthingscherokee.com/articles_gene_040101.html |archive-date=June 10, 2009 |access-date=2009-09-07 |publisher=All Things Cherokee, personal website}}</ref><ref name="5doll2">{{cite web |last1=Landry |first1=Alysa |date=27 March 2017 |title=Paying to Play Indian: The Dawes Rolls and the Legacy of $5 Indians |url=https://newsmaven.io/indiancountrytoday/archive/paying-to-play-indian-the-dawes-rolls-and-the-legacy-of-5-indians-3yha0LldYUaH7smRsrks8A/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190110061958/https://newsmaven.io/indiancountrytoday/archive/paying-to-play-indian-the-dawes-rolls-and-the-legacy-of-5-indians-3yha0LldYUaH7smRsrks8A/ |archive-date=10 January 2019 |access-date=23 May 2019 |website=IndianCountryToday.com |language=en}}</ref> In some cases, blood quantum has strained families and relationships. <ref>{{Cite book |last=Villazor |first=Rose Cuison |url=https://uncp.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/fulldisplay?docid=cdi_proquest_journals_204122356&context=PC&vid=01UONCAP_INST:UONCAP&lang=en&search_scope=MyInst_and_CI&adaptor=Primo%20Central&tab=Everything&query=any,contains,blood%20quantum%20and%20native%20american&offset=20&pcAvailability=true |title=Blood Quantum Land Laws and the Race versus Political Identity Dilemma |publisher=[[Berkeley: School of Law, University of California, Berkeley]]}}</ref>
At certain times, some state governments classified persons with [[African American]] and Native American admixture solely as African American, largely because of racial discrimination related to slavery history and the concept of the [[one drop rule]]. This was prevalent in the [[Southern United States|South]] after [[Reconstruction Era of the United States|Reconstruction]], when white-dominated legislatures imposed legal [[Racial segregation in the United States|segregation]], which classified the entire population only as white or colored (Native Americans, some of whom were of mixed race, were included in the latter designation).
It related to the racial caste system of slavery before the [[American Civil War]]. Some critics argue that blood quantum laws helped create racism among tribal members. The historian Tony Seybert contends that was why some members of the so-called [[Five Civilized tribes]] were slaveholders. The majority of slave owners were of mixed-European ancestry. Some believed they were of higher status than full-blood Indians and people of African ancestry.<ref name="amslav2">{{cite web |author=Tony Seybert |year=2009 |title=Slavery and Native Americans in British North America and the United States: 1600 to 1865 |url=http://www.slaveryinamerica.org/history/hs_es_indians_slavery.htm |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040804001522/http://www.slaveryinamerica.org/history/hs_es_indians_slavery.htm |archive-date=2004-08-04 |access-date=2009-06-20 |publisher=New York Life}}</ref><ref name="cat2">{{cite web |author=William Loren Katz |year=2008 |title=Africans and Indians: Only in America |url=http://www.williamlkatz.com/Essays/History/AfricansIndians.php |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513235755/http://www.williamlkatz.com/Essays/History/AfricansIndians.php |archive-date=May 13, 2008 |access-date=2008-09-20 |publisher=William Loren Katz}}</ref> Other historians contend that the Cherokee and other tribes held slaves because it was in their economic interest and part of the general southeastern culture. Cherokee and other tribes had also traditionally taken captives in warfare to use as slaves, though their institution differed from what developed in the southern colonies.
===Population decline due to exogamy=== Nationwide, 54-61% of all Native Americans [[Exogamy|marry non-Natives]], which is a much higher rate than for any other racial group.<ref>{{cite web |title=Interracial marriage: Who is 'marrying out'? |date=12 June 2015 |url=http://pewrsr.ch/1C2VmlJ}}</ref> It is projected that the [[Minnesota Chippewa Tribe]] will experience a gradual population decrease in the coming decades, unless it lowers its current membership requirement of at least 25% Native ancestry,<ref>{{cite web |title=Minnesota Chippewa Tribe: Population Projections |url=https://www.mnchippewatribe.org/pdf/MCT%20Population%20Projections.pdf |access-date=28 June 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=MartinRogers, Ph.d. |first1=Nicole |last2=Gillaspy, Ph.d. |first2=Tom |title=Minnesota Chippewa Tribe Population Projections Methodology Report |url=https://www.mnchippewatribe.org/pdf/MCT%20Methodology%20Report.pdf |access-date=28 June 2024 |date=May 2014}}</ref> as a consequence of tribal members having children with non-Native Americans for several generations.
== Issues with DNA ancestry testing == No [[Federally recognized tribes|federally recognized tribe]] enrolls members solely based on DNA testing, as it generally cannot distinguish among tribes.<ref name="genej2">{{cite web |author1=Brett Lee Shelton |author2=J.D. and Jonathan Marks |year=2008 |title=Genetic Markers Not a Valid Test of Native Identity |url=http://www.ipcb.org/publications/briefing_papers/files/identity.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725075627/http://www.ipcb.org/publications/briefing_papers/files/identity.html |archive-date=2008-07-25 |access-date=2008-10-02 |publisher=Counsel for Responsible Genetics}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Tribal Enrollment and Genetic Testing - Genetics |url=http://genetics.ncai.org/tribal-enrollment-and-genetic-testing.cfm |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181228110603/http://genetics.ncai.org/tribal-enrollment-and-genetic-testing.cfm |archive-date=2018-12-28 |access-date=2017-10-28 |website=genetics.ncai.org}}</ref> Some tribes may require DNA testing only to document that a child is related to particular parents. Many researchers have published articles that caution that genetic ancestry DNA testing has limitations and should not be depended on by individuals to answer all their questions about heritage.<ref name="true22">{{cite web |author=ScienceDaily |year=2008 |title=Genetic Ancestral Testing Cannot Deliver On Its Promise, Study Warns |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/10/071018145955.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080611201201/http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/10/071018145955.htm |archive-date=2008-06-11 |access-date=2008-10-02 |website=ScienceDaily}}</ref><ref name="hr2">{{cite news |author=Troy Duster |year=2008 |title=Deep Roots and Tangled Branches |url=http://www.geneticsandsociety.org/article.php?id=3908 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726082531/http://www.geneticsandsociety.org/article.php?id=3908 |archive-date=2011-07-26 |access-date=2008-10-02 |newspaper=Chronicle of Higher Education}}</ref>
Many African Americans believe they have some Native American ancestry. But, in the [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] series led by historian [[Henry Louis Gates Jr.]], called ''[[African American Lives]]'', geneticists said DNA evidence shows that Native American ancestry is far less common than previously believed; of the group tested in the series, only two of the people showed likely Native ancestry.<ref name="African American Lives2">{{Cite web |date=2009-03-13 |title="African American Lives" - "African American Lives" is a PBS Series about Race and DNA |url=http://racerelations.about.com/od/ahistoricalviewofrace/a/dnaandrace.htm |access-date=2024-03-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090313231943/http://racerelations.about.com/od/ahistoricalviewofrace/a/dnaandrace.htm |archive-date=2009-03-13 }}</ref><ref name="African American Lives PBS2">{{cite web |title=African American Lives 2 |url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/aalives/dna/index.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171101021222/http://www.pbs.org/wnet/aalives/dna/index.html |archive-date=2017-11-01 |access-date=2017-08-24 |website=[[PBS]]}}</ref>
Only 5 percent of African Americans have at least one-eighth Native American ancestry (equivalent to one great-grandparent). On the other hand, nearly 78 percent of African Americans have at least one-eighth European ancestry (the equivalent to one great-grandparent), and nearly 20 percent have at least one-quarter European ancestry (the equivalent to one grandparent.)<ref>Henry Louis Gates, Jr., ''In Search of Our Roots: How 19 Extraordinary African Americans Reclaimed Their Past'', New York: Crown Publishing, 2009, pp. 20-21</ref>
In response, one critic asserted the percentage must be higher because there are so many family stories (the reasons for which Gates and, notably, [[Chris Rock]] explored in the documentary), but felt that many people did not always talk about it because to acknowledge it would be to deny their African heritage.<ref name="dstu22">{{cite web |author=Sherrel Wheeler Stewart |year=2008 |title=More Blacks are Exploring the African-American/Native American Connection |url=http://www.rlnn.com/ArtOct06/MoreBlacksAfricanAmerNativeAmerConnection.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061031200938/http://www.rlnn.com/ArtOct06/MoreBlacksAfricanAmerNativeAmerConnection.html |archive-date=2006-10-31 |access-date=2008-08-06 |publisher=BlackAmericaWeb.com}}</ref>
Some critics thought the PBS series ''African American Lives'' did not sufficiently explain such limitations of DNA testing for assessment of heritage.<ref name="hr22">{{cite news |author=Troy Duster |year=2008 |title=Deep Roots and Tangled Branches |url=http://www.geneticsandsociety.org/article.php?id=3908 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726082531/http://www.geneticsandsociety.org/article.php?id=3908 |archive-date=2011-07-26 |access-date=2008-10-02 |newspaper=Chronicle of Higher Education}}</ref> In terms of persons searching for ethnic ancestry, they need to understand that [[Y chromosome|Y-chromosome]] and [[Mitochondrial DNA|mtDNA]] (mitochondrial DNA) testing looks only at "direct" line male and female ancestors, and thus can fail to pick up many other ancestors' heritage.<ref name="genej22">{{cite web |author1=Brett Lee Shelton |author2=J.D. and Jonathan Marks |year=2008 |title=Genetic Markers Not a Valid Test of Native Identity |url=http://www.ipcb.org/publications/briefing_papers/files/identity.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725075627/http://www.ipcb.org/publications/briefing_papers/files/identity.html |archive-date=2008-07-25 |access-date=2008-10-02 |publisher=Counsel for Responsible Genetics}}</ref> Newer DNA tests can survey all the DNA that can be inherited from either parent of an individual, but at a cost of precision. DNA tests that survey the full DNA strand focus on "[[Single-nucleotide polymorphism|single nucleotide polymorphisms]]" or SNPs, but SNPs might be found in Africans, Asians, and people from every other part of the world. Full survey DNA testing cannot accurately determine an individual's full ancestry.<ref name="jh2">{{cite news |author=John Hawks |year=2008 |title=How African Are You? What genealogical testing can't tell you. |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2138059 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100710051010/http://www.slate.com/id/2138059 |archive-date=2010-07-10 |access-date=2010-06-26 |newspaper=Washington Post}}</ref> Though DNA testing for ancestry is limited more recent genetic testing research of 2015, have found that varied ancestries show different tendencies by region and sex of ancestors. These studies found that on average, African Americans have 73.2–82.1% [[West African people|West African]], 16.7%–29% [[Europe|European]], and 0.8–2% [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] genetic ancestry, with large variation between individuals.<ref name="Bryc20092">{{cite journal |author1=Katarzyna Bryc |author2=Adam Auton |author3=Matthew R. A notable debate in 2019 over the validity of DNA testing for Native American ancestry arose over the [[Elizabeth Warren#Ancestry and Native American claims|controversies surrounding Elizabeth Warren's ancestry]].
== Issues with tribal rolls == Basing citizenship off specific enrollment rolls, like the [[Dawes Rolls|Dawes Roll]] (that were taken after more than 80 years after Removal, after the [[Civil war|Civil War]], and after tribal government restructuring), is what scholar Fay A. Yarbrough calls "dramatically different from older conceptions" of tribal identity based on clan relationships, "in which individuals could be fully," for example, "Cherokee without possessing any Cherokee ancestry." And that by the tribe later "developing a quantifiable definition of Cherokee identity based on ancestry," this "would dramatically affect the process of enrollment late in the nineteenth century and the modern procedure of obtaining membership in the Cherokee Nation, both of which require tracing and individuals’ lineage to a ‘Cherokee by blood.’" Thus, the Dawes Roll still upholds "by blood" language and theory of its time even though the tribe does not require blood quantum.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Yarbrough |first=Fay A. |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n1onAgAAQBAJ&q=Understanding%20Cherokee%20identity%20as%20a%20measure%20of%20ancestry%20or%20heredity |title=Race and the Cherokee Nation Sovereignty in the Nineteenth Century |date=21 November 2013 |publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press |isbn=9780812290172 |page=43 |access-date=18 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230722153600/https://books.google.com/books?id=n1onAgAAQBAJ&q=Understanding%20Cherokee%20identity%20as%20a%20measure%20of%20ancestry%20or%20heredity |archive-date=22 July 2023 |url-status=live}}</ref> Author Robert J. Conley has stated that if a tribe like the Cherokee Nation are "really serious about exercising its sovereignty and determining its membership," then it should not use the roll that "was put together by the U.S. government and then closed by the U.S. government," meaning that a tribal nation is still subject to the settler definitions of its members when other outside nations do not require rolls, ethnicity, race, or blood quantum for citizenship, but rather birth location and descendance.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Conley |first=Robert |url=https://archive.org/details/cherokeethoughts0000conl/page/152/mode/2up?q=my+sister+CDIB |title=Cherokee thoughts, honest and uncensored |publisher=University of Oklahoma Press |year=2008 |isbn=9780806139432 |pages=153–166}}</ref>
== U.S. Census == The U.S. Census is conducted every 10 years and is used to get a population count.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Armstrong |first=Marc |url= |title=U.S. Census Bureau Area Measurements for Sub-County Areas and Clarence Batschelet's U.S. Population Density Map of 1942 |publisher=[[Abingdon: Routledge]]}}</ref> The National Research Council noted in 1996, "The U.S. census decennial enumerations indicate a Native American population growth for the United States that has been nearly continuous since 1900 (except for an [[1918 flu pandemic|influenza epidemic]] in 1918 that caused serious losses), to 1.42 million by 1980 and to over 1.9 million by 1990."<ref name="naaa4">{{cite book |author=Russell Thornton |url=https://archive.org/details/changingnumbersc0000unse |title=Tribal Membership Requirements and the Demography of "Old" and "New" Native Americans |publisher=[[The National Academic Press]] |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-309-05548-2 |doi=10.17226/5355 |pmid=25121291 |access-date=2009-09-02 |url-access=registration}}</ref> In the 2000 census, there were 2.5 million Native Americans. Since 1960, people may self-identify their ancestry on the US Census.<ref name="naaa4" /> Native American activism and a rising interest in Native American history appear to have resulted in more individuals identifying as having Native American ancestry on the census.
==Implementation== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Blood Quantum (2).jpg|thumb|284x284px|Figure 1, This shows how blood quantum works]] --> Many Native American tribes continue to employ blood quantum in current tribal laws to determine who is eligible for membership or citizenship in the tribe or Native American nation. These often require a minimum degree of blood relationship and often an ancestor listed in a specific tribal [[census]] from the late 19th century or early 20th century. The [[Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians]] of [[North Carolina]], for example, require an ancestor listed in the 1924 Baker census and a minimum of 1/16 Cherokee blood inherited from their ancestor(s) on that roll. Meanwhile, the [[Cherokee Nation]] requires applicants to descend from an ancestor in the 1906 [[Dawes Rolls|Dawes roll]] (direct lineal ancestry), but does not impose minimum blood quantum requirement. The [[United Keetoowah Band]] requires a minimum 1/4 blood quantum.
The [[Mashantucket Pequot]] tribe on the other hand, base their tribal membership on an individual proving descent, by recognized genealogical documentation from one or more members of the eleven families included on the 1900 US census of the tribe.<ref name="peqgaming2">{{cite web |last1=Hauptman |first1=Laurence M. |title="A Review" of Jeff Benedict's ''Without Reservation: The Making of America's Most Powerful Indian Tribe and Foxwoods, the World's Largest Casino Indian Gaming'' |url=http://www.indiangaming.org/library/articles/novel-attack.shtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012032535/http://www.indiangaming.org/library/articles/novel-attack.shtml |archive-date=12 October 2008 |access-date=29 May 2019}}</ref>
The [[Northern Ute Tribe]] require a 5/8 blood quantum, making them the only tribe to require a number greater than 1/2. The [[Miccosukee]] of [[Florida]], the [[Mississippi Choctaw]], and the [[St. Croix Band of Chippewa Indians|St. Croix Chippewa]] of [[Wisconsin]] all require one-half "tribal blood quantum", also among the higher percentages.
At the other end of the scale, some tribes, such as the [[Kaw Nation]],<ref name="Constitution of the Kaw Nation.2">[http://kawnation.com/?page_id=3312 "Constitution of the Kaw Nation."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190803003621/http://kawnation.com/?page_id=3312|date=2019-08-03}} ''Kaw Nation.'' 2011. Retrieved 30 April 2012.</ref> have no blood quantum requirement.
Many tribes, such as [[Alabama-Quassarte Tribal Town]] and the [[Wyandotte Nation]],<ref name="oia2">[http://www.ok.gov/oiac/Publications/ "Pocket Pictorial."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100406044653/http://www.ok.gov/oiac/Publications/|date=2010-04-06}} ''Oklahoma Indian Affairs Commission.'' 2010. (retrieved 10 June 2010)</ref> require an unspecified amount of Indian ancestry (known as "[[lineal descendancy]]") documented by descent from a recognized member. Others require a specified degree of Indian ancestry but an unspecified share of ancestry from the ancestral tribe or tribes from which the contemporary tribal entity is derived, such as the [[Grand Traverse Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians]] and the [[Poarch Band of Creek Indians]].<ref>[http://www.narf.org/nill/Constitutions/poarchconstitution/poarchconst.htm "Constitution of the Poarch Band of Creek Indians."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081128083033/http://www.narf.org/nill/Constitutions/poarchconstitution/poarchconst.htm|date=2008-11-28}} ''[[Native American Rights Fund]].'' 1 June 1985 (retrieved 25 Nov 2010)</ref> Many tribes today are confederations of different ethnic groups joined into a single political entity making the determination of blood quantum challenging.
Other tribes require a minimum blood degree only for tribal members born "off" (outside) the nominal [[Indian reservation|reservation]]. This is a concept comparable to a combination of the legal principles of ''[[Jus soli]]'' and ''[[Jus sanguinis]]'' in the [[Nationality law|nationality laws]] of modern sovereign states.
The [[Red Lake Nation]] of Minnesota declared in 2019 that all original enrollees on the tribe's 1958 roll were to be "considered full-bloods", regardless of their actual blood quantum as recorded on the roll.<ref>[https://www.redlakenation.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Red-Lake-Tribal-Council-Passes-New-Resolution-to-Change-Blood-Degree-of-Members.jpg Resolution notice] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200721095104/https://www.redlakenation.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Red-Lake-Tribal-Council-Passes-New-Resolution-to-Change-Blood-Degree-of-Members.jpg|date=2020-07-21}} redlakenation.org</ref> Since the tribal blood requirement for membership was (and still is) 1/4, the implication of this "resetting" of the original tribal members' blood quantum is that the grandchild of a person on the 1958 roll who was recorded as 1/4 Chippewa is now eligible for tribal membership, thus effectively setting the requirement at 1/16.

==Similar usage== In [[Australia]], the racial laws inflicted on the [[Stolen Generations]] have been compared to blood quantum laws, as mixed-race [[Indigenous Australian]] children were removed from their families to biologically absorb them into the white population under the assumption that full-blooded individuals were doomed to extinction.
